title: MG & Friendships

content: Sometimes, I feel I’m walking on a tightrope between managing my health and maintaining relationships.

After years of dealing with myasthenia gravis (MG), I’ve mastered the health parts. But I still struggle in the friendship department. One of the most challenging parts of this journey is dealing with the frustrations of not being fully understood by my friends.
Often, they fail to grasp the complex struggles I face daily. They offer well-meaning, yet misplaced, advice. They make assumptions that lead me to feelings of isolation and disconnection.
In this post, we’ll explore ways to bridge the gap of understanding to maintain meaningful relationships while chronically ill.

I believe the disconnect of understanding, when it comes to chronic illness, is the invisible nature of it all. People hear you’re dealing with a lifelong disease and expect you to look like it. In reality, chronic illness, especially MG, looks different on everyone.

There isn’t one way to present. Common misconceptions like “You don’t look sick” invalidate those of us living with invisible illnesses. The invisible aspect makes it hard for others to understand, but communicating those unseen struggles out loud helps.

content: I have the most success getting friends to understand my plight when I communicate effectively. I start the friendship by setting clear expectations. This looks like letting friends know upfront my needs, limitations, and boundaries.

For example, most of my friends live an hour or more away. I can’t comfortably drive for more than half an hour on a good day, and my friends understand this. That’s one limitation I have. Communicating with them about these things early on can help bridge gaps of misunderstanding.
Educating your friends about your condition is another way to help them understand.

Sometimes I randomly shoot over a blog or infographic about MG to my friends. If I’m struggling to find the right words to explain a symptom, I use resources from an MG organization or site to help. Usually, real friends are open to learning more about your disease.

content: Having a basic understanding of MG helps a ton when it comes to selecting outings, activities, etc. For example, my friends wouldn’t suggest we rock climb or run a mile. They understand that my voluntary muscles tire out quickly, and only suggest activities that are accommodating.

content: While it can be incredibly disheartening when friends don’t understand the realities of living with a chronic illness, it's important to remember they may simply have a lack of awareness, not a lack of caring.

By approaching these situations with patience and clear communication, you can help bridge the gap and foster a deeper understanding in others. Surrounding yourself with a network of people who respect and value your experiences can make a significant difference in your journey. If you feel misunderstood in your friendships, I encourage you to seek support from those dealing with your same situation or health condition.
